title: of 1972) and for the purpose of giving further effect to Regulation (EU) No.
heading: 1. (1) These Regulations may be cited as the European Union (Interchange
text_raw:
1. (1) These Regulations may be cited as the European Union (Interchange 

Fees for Card-based Payment Transactions) (Amendment) Regulations 2020. 

(2) These Regulations shall come into operation on 9 December 2020.
text_norm: 1 (1) regulation may cited european union (interchange fee card-based payment transactions) (amendment) regulation 2020 (2) regulation shall come operation 9 december 2020

title: of 1972) and for the purpose of giving further effect to Regulation (EU) No.
heading: 2. The European Union (Interchange Fees for Card-based Payment
text_raw:
2. The European Union (Interchange Fees for Card-based Payment 
Transactions) Regulations 2015 (S.I. No. 550 of 2015) are amended by the 
substitution of the following Regulation for Regulation 5: 

“5. Payment service providers shall not offer or request a per transaction 
interchange fee of more than 0.10% of the value of the transaction for any 
domestic debit card transaction.”. 

GIVEN under my Official Seal, 

12 November, 2020. 

PASCHAL DONOHOE, 

Minister for Finance. 

1 OJ L 123, 19.05.2015, p.1 

Notice of the making of this Statutory Instrument was published in 
 “Iris Oifigiúil” of 17th November, 2020. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 [525] 3

title: of 1972) and for the purpose of giving further effect to Regulation (EU) No.
heading: (This note is not part of the instrument and does not purport to be a legal
text_raw:
EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

This Statutory Instrument (SI) amends SI 751 of 2015 on Interchange Fees. 

Regulation 5 of SI 751 of 2015 is replaced in order to update a provision that 
falls away on the 09 December 2020. This was a discretion contained in the 
Interchange Fee Regulation that Ireland chose to avail of in 2015. 

The change to the existing legislation involves the replacement of a weighted 
average approach set out in Regulation 5 to capping interchange fees for 
consumer debit transactions with a per transaction cap approach. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4 [525]
